Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Nonoperative Treatment and Hemiarthroplasty for Four-Part Proximal Humerus Fractures in the Elderly

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 50 patients aged 65 years and older with four-part proximal humerus fractures were randomly allocated to nonoperative treatment or hemiarthroplasty.

Participants.evidence: 50 patients aged 65 years and older with four-part proximal humerus fractures

Intervention.evidence: randomly allocated to nonoperative treatment or hemiarthroplasty

Objective.evidence: This study compares nonoperative treatment and hemiarthroplasty in terms of function, strength, and pain.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Constant-Murley score at 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 12 months, there were no significant differences between groups in Constant-Murley and Simple Shoulder Test scores.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
